Answer: The biggest transformation will be in the killer app for VR/XR: community.Right now, meeting rooms with Avatars (such as Oculus Go rooms) are still crude, interaction is limited, and the avatars are unrealistic. Improvements coming are higher bandwidth (coming with 5G), realistic bodies and faces (cheap 3D modeling of heads is already possible with the iPhone 11), and motion capture for both bodies and mouths for speech. That will enable realistic meeting 3D meeting rooms for people thousands of miles away, and that will change everything: telemedicine, telehealth, business and social meetingsThe biggest transformation will be in the killer app for VR/XR: community.Right now, meeting rooms with Avatars (such as Oculus Go rooms) are still crude, interaction is limited, and the avatars are unrealistic. Improvements coming are higher bandwidth (coming with 5G), realistic bodies and faces (cheap 3D modeling of heads is already possible with the iPhone 11), and motion capture for both bodies and mouths for speech. That will enable realistic meeting 3D meeting rooms for people thousands of miles away, and that will change everything: telemedicine, telehealth, business and social meetings, book and wine and special interest group gatherings, group therapy, etc.Less travel for meetings means less pollution, fewer accidents, etc. The technology will have to show not only facial movements, but high-rez movements resulting from emotions.It would be terrific to have that capability already in this period of quarantine and coronavirus.

Answer: You may not be old enough to remember the first Star Trek. Spock kidnapped his old captain, and hijacked the Enterprise to go to a forbidden planet. Turned out The Old Captain had discovered it. On it were an an advanced race of intelligent beings. They had rescued a woman from a crashed star ship. But had mucked up the reassembly of her body. But they had been able to adjust her reality to where she was normal. The Old Captain was now in an advance wheel chair, but unable to do anymore than move his head. Unable to communicate. The upshot is that when he got to this planet, he was given a newYou may not be old enough to remember the first Star Trek. Spock kidnapped his old captain, and hijacked the Enterprise to go to a forbidden planet. Turned out The Old Captain had discovered it. On it were an an advanced race of intelligent beings. They had rescued a woman from a crashed star ship. But had mucked up the reassembly of her body. But they had been able to adjust her reality to where she was normal. The Old Captain was now in an advance wheel chair, but unable to do anymore than move his head. Unable to communicate. The upshot is that when he got to this planet, he was given a new lease on life with the woman. To walk around freely, talk and engage with others physically. That was Sci-Fi 50 years ago.That is where I think VR/AR might be in 50 years. In technological terms, 50 years is a long time. I have other ideas on what will be probably, based on what we know today. I‚Äôve written on here about some of it. This Virus maybe the last hurrah for viral infections, along with most if not all human maladies. Like Flight 130 years ago, many will call me (and others) crazy for thinking things will advance so far. But looking back 50 years, no one thought we would be watching weather on home computers in real time, or have electric vehicles, or land orbital class boosters. Stuff that is becoming common place. AR/VR might even qualify for Holo Deck in 50 years, or will it be closer to shape shifting that takes the cake ? :D

Answer: Fifteen years ago, when I was a young buck? Politically comatose? Stupid? Na√Øve?In a heartbeat.Travel the galaxy. See exotic planets. Meet fascinating people (and aliens, and Greek gods, and space Nazis). Lecture them about goodness and wisdom and temperance and free will, and double-punch and fly-kick them into submission if they don‚Äôt listen.Can you tell what my answer would be today?Hell no.I don‚Äôt trust Starfleet‚Äîwhich is itself only the enforcement (excuse me, ‚Äúpeacekeeping‚Äù) arm of the United Federation of Planets‚Äîas far as I could throw it.I don‚Äôt care if they made me the helmsman on aFifteen years ago, when I was a young buck? Politically comatose? Stupid? Na√Øve?In a heartbeat.Travel the galaxy. See exotic planets. Meet fascinating people (and aliens, and Greek gods, and space Nazis). Lecture them about goodness and wisdom and temperance and free will, and double-punch and fly-kick them into submission if they don‚Äôt listen.Can you tell what my answer would be today?Hell no.I don‚Äôt trust Starfleet‚Äîwhich is itself only the enforcement (excuse me, ‚Äúpeacekeeping‚Äù) arm of the United Federation of Planets‚Äîas far as I could throw it.I don‚Äôt care if they made me the helmsman on aI don‚Äôt care if the navigator sitting next to me was aHell, I don‚Äôt even care if they assigned me to the same ship as Yeoman Rand.Mmm‚Ä¶Yeoman Rand‚Ä¶Sorry, where was I?[Like I was saying, I have serious misgivings about any organization that bills itself as ‚Äúinter-‚Äù something. International agencies like Interpol? International governments like the European Union? An ‚Äúinterstellar government‚Äù like the Federation? They give me the willies. They leave me with too many questions. What necessitated the formation of the Federation, anyway? Why does it need its own president, its own legislature, and more importantly, its own military? Who is the Federation‚Äôs leadership accountable to? How much say do its members have, really? What mechanisms exist for punishing abuses of power and penalizing or removing the offenders? How effective are those mechanisms, and how often have they been used? How free is the average citizen of the Federation and how are those freedoms codified and protected? Perhaps most importantly of all, how is Starfleet funded? Who‚Äôs paying for all those shot-up starships in drydock to be put back together again?Even assuming that the answers to these questions would satisfy me, I justThe hegemonic nature of the Federation is problematic, too. Starfleet has shown itself to be perfectly willing to use force to subdue anything it deems hostile. While claiming to be all about peaceful coexistence and cooperation, the Federation sends an armada of heavily armed warships cruising through space, ready to blast anything that violates its statutes or threatens its interests. (I‚Äôm fairly certain there‚Äôs a Cardassian or two who has pointed this out.) The message seems to be ‚ÄúOur way or the highway,‚Äù with ‚Äúhighway‚Äù here having the meaning of ‚Äúa photon torpedo up the bum.‚Äù This is exactly the same sort of criticism the United States gets for its force projection and so-called ‚Äúpeacekeeping efforts‚Äù worldwide. Why is everyone so willing to overlook gunboat diplomacy when a fictitious, snappily uniformed interstellar coalition does it?Starfleet is just‚Ä¶I dunno. Too iffy for me. When I enlist, I like to be sure that whatever I‚Äôm enlisting in serves a truly vital (and noble) purpose and isn‚Äôt merely a tool of oppression or banditry. Starfleet‚Äîand the United Federation of Planets it serves‚Äîjust seems too big, too powerful, and too idealistic (idealism usually masks heavy-handedness, thuggery, and incompetence) to be trustworthy.

So it just seems like there‚Äôs nothing more than that. Answer: As of yesterday it‚Äôs no longer ‚Äúnext‚Äù.First pig heart being transplanted into a humanYesterday, January 10th, 2022, marks the first time an organ from a genetically modified animal, a pig, was transplanted into a human. We don‚Äôt know what will happen, but the pig was genetically modified in a way that makes it unlikely the organ will be rejected by the recepient and pig organs in general are quite similar to our own.I hope the recipient lives a rich full life with his new heart of a pig. Even if not, this is still a major step forward towards generating organs to order, without fear of rejectiAs of yesterday it‚Äôs no longer ‚Äúnext‚Äù.First pig heart being transplanted into a humanYesterday, January 10th, 2022, marks the first time an organ from a genetically modified animal, a pig, was transplanted into a human. We don‚Äôt know what will happen, but the pig was genetically modified in a way that makes it unlikely the organ will be rejected by the recepient and pig organs in general are quite similar to our own.I hope the recipient lives a rich full life with his new heart of a pig. Even if not, this is still a major step forward towards generating organs to order, without fear of rejection. Even if the heart is rejected and the donor dies, what we learn from the process will enable us to succeed the next time. I reckon this will become the mainstream way we get spare parts by the end of the decade in an optimistic scenario, by the end of the next decade in the pessimistic one.Either way, the moment is as groundbreaking as December 3rd, 1967, when the first human heart ever was transplanted, ushering the era of organ transplants of today. That patient died after 18 days, I hope this guy does better.

Answer: Transcription is not a solved problem. The error rates are significant when you are not in anThe field has been on the hype cycle every year since the mid-90s, and it's always been about 5 years away. The profile got raised with smartphones specifically because smartphones have the lousiest human-to-machine information transmission bandwidths of most computing platforms around (smartwatchesTranscription is not a solved problem. The error rates are significant when you are not in anThe field has been on the hype cycle every year since the mid-90s, and it's always been about 5 years away. The profile got raised with smartphones specifically because smartphones have the lousiest human-to-machine information transmission bandwidths of most computing platforms around (smartwatches/wearables are worse). I have owned Glass for two years now and those buggers haven't implemented any usable solution to the cocktail party problem.Almost everyone these days uses a cloud based approach to this problem - which on paper is great, but UX is not as efficient as mechanical input - you wait for about a second or two and you are never sure if the result is going to be correct. In my experience, it gets all uncommon words (specially technical words - guess what the key early adopters demographic generally thinks about?) incorrect. If I have to repeat myself 5 times putting effort into adapting my voice for the machine to understand what I am saying, I really don't have any business claiming speech-transcription is solved.The core problem in the transcription business is that human communication is not a 1xN array problem, it is a MxN array problem - we use visual and psychological cues to infer context and speech. Since transcription algos don't use any of that data, those solutions are going to be forever inefficient.Another aspect is that all current implementations are just software driven efforts. There's no commercial adoption of multi-array microphone technology or selective filtering based on environmental/ambient knowledge. This trend is only going to get worse over the next two/three years while ML/big data goes over the inflated expectations peak.

Answer: It'll never become "the next big thing" because it isn't happening all at once, it is slowly creeping into our consciousness.   Within the last two years, it has gone from a novelty add-on that slows down your phone to a really useful tool. But that's for short texts and emails.It will probably never take over offices because it would be annoying to have a  whole office of people talking all at once.    But it is slowly becoming more and more useful in more and more places, and I don't see any end to that trend any time soon.

Answer: Transfer learning in ML models.Humans are really good at generalizing. We only have to see a few dogs before we can recognize a dog when we see one.Machines are not. ML models require millions of examples before forming a reliable classifier, and that classifier is very specific to the data on which it was trained. If your training data doesn't include dogs with three legs, the model won't recognize them. A machine that plays Go is useless at checkers.Transfer learning is the ability to apply a model from one domain to a different one. It's hypothesized that the reason humans learn so quicklyTransfer learning in ML models.Humans are really good at generalizing. We only have to see a few dogs before we can recognize a dog when we see one.Machines are not. ML models require millions of examples before forming a reliable classifier, and that classifier is very specific to the data on which it was trained. If your training data doesn't include dogs with three legs, the model won't recognize them. A machine that plays Go is useless at checkers.Transfer learning is the ability to apply a model from one domain to a different one. It's hypothesized that the reason humans learn so quickly is that we are fitting new examples into our existing knowledge rather than forming entirely new categories. If we could teach machines to do the same, they would learn exponentially faster and apply that learning more effectively.Transfer learning is a very hot topic in AI research right now, so I expect major breakthroughs in the next few years. I think this may be sufficient to achieve artificial general intelligence, but even if not, it will dramatically extend the range of tasks that machines can accomplish.

Answer: Technology being by design a fleeting concept, journalists, entrepreneurs and investors are endlessly looking to make big bucks by noticing and investing in the famed Next Big Thing. So much so that they sometimes lose their head in the process and spew out very silly things. This happy crowd of predictors often fails to see the irony of using history, which is at heart the study of surprises and changes, as a guide to the future. In doing so, they over-rely on past data as a signal to future conditions in a field where innovation and change is the lifeblood of progress.Virtual reality (VR) anTechnology being by design a fleeting concept, journalists, entrepreneurs and investors are endlessly looking to make big bucks by noticing and investing in the famed Next Big Thing. So much so that they sometimes lose their head in the process and spew out very silly things. This happy crowd of predictors often fails to see the irony of using history, which is at heart the study of surprises and changes, as a guide to the future. In doing so, they over-rely on past data as a signal to future conditions in a field where innovation and change is the lifeblood of progress.Virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) are not new concepts but will revolutionize the world within 5 years. AR enhances reality while VR helps us forget it. Together, they open a world beyond reality, the internet or the internet of things; a new industry, the internet of experiences, is emerging.Companies are realising thatTo more know details
